text:
2.1 Churn rate by Tenure bins (0-6, 6-12, 12-24, 24-48, 48+)
Tenure is how long a customer has been with the company (in months). Following is the hypothesis,

Customer who are new (short tenure) are more likely to churn; customers who have stayed longer are “stickier”

To test this,

Group customers into bins of tenure (0-6 months, 6-12, etc.).
Compute churn rate = (# churned customers) / (total customers) in each bin.
Plot churn rate across bins to visualize patterns.

If churn is very high in 0-6 months bin, that means the company has an onboarding / early experience problem.

The random forest importance table shows that Contract is the most influential predictor of churn, with the highest values in both MeanDecreaseAccuracy (44.71) and MeanDecreaseGini (79.11). MonthlyCharges, Age, TotalCharges, and Tenure also contribute meaningfully, though at lower levels, indicating that financial and tenure-related variables affect churn risk. InternetService, Gender, and PhoneService have much smaller importance scores, suggesting they add little predictive value. Overall, contract type dominates as the key driver, followed by monetary and tenure factors, while demographic or service-type variables play a minor role in predicting churn.
